notes.title: URDF import in Isaacsim
notes.content:
In Isaacsim V5 by default, as per the instructions, when I tried to source the ROS2 workspace and tried to import the UR5e URDF, it was causing errors.
What worked so far is using the absolute paths to mesh files.

Secondly, having conflicting frame names like 'world' or 'World' dint seem like a problem.

All additional ROS 2-specific tags didn't cause any trouble in the import procedure.

Initially, the movements of the joints seemed very abrupt. After setting the natural frequency to 300 for all the joints, it stabilized.

Similarly, on putting the natural frequency as 300 for the Robotiq gripper, it got stabilized as well.

Basically for all the position based joints the natural frequency is set to 300 and for all the mimic joints, its set to 2500

Two errors that consistently showed up and dint get resolved yet 
 - Limits not set for the left inner knuckle joint.
 - Multiple reference joints for the left inner knuckle joint.


# Run this in Script Editor (Python) after your robot is loaded

import math
import omni.usd
from pxr import Usd, Sdf, UsdPhysics   # Revolute joint attributes live here
from pxr import PhysxSchema            # PhysxMimicJointAPI (multiple-apply schema)

stage: Usd.Stage = omni.usd.get_context().get_stage()  # correct way to get the current stage in Kit apps
# (Docs: omni.usd UsdContext/get_stage)  # https://docs.omniverse.nvidia.com/dev-guide/latest/programmer_ref/usd/stage/get-current-stage.html

def set_single_reference(follower_prim_path: str, source_joint_path: str):
    prim = stage.GetPrimAtPath(follower_prim_path)
    if not prim.IsValid():
        print("Invalid prim:", follower_prim_path); return
    # A prim can have multiple mimic-API instances (rotX/rotY/rotZ). Fix all of them.
    for api in PhysxSchema.PhysxMimicJointAPI.GetAll(prim):
        # Keep exactly one referenceJoint target
        rel = api.GetReferenceJointRel()
        rel.ClearTargets(True)              # clear authored targets across the layer stack
        rel.AddTarget(Sdf.Path(source_joint_path))
        # Ensure gearing/offset exist (matches URDF defaults)
        if api.GetGearingAttr().Get() is None:
            api.CreateGearingAttr(1.0)
        if api.GetOffsetAttr().Get() is None:
            api.CreateOffsetAttr(0.0)
        #print(f"[OK] {follower_prim_path} -> reference {source_joint_path} (instance {api.GetName()})")

def set_revolute_limits_rad(joint_path: str, lower_rad: float, upper_rad: float):
    """
    Author finite limits on a UsdPhysics.RevoluteJoint. Converts radians->degrees for USD.
    """
    prim = stage.GetPrimAtPath(joint_path)
    if not prim.IsValid():
        print("Invalid prim:", joint_path); return
    if not prim.IsA(UsdPhysics.RevoluteJoint):
        print("Not a UsdPhysics.RevoluteJoint:", joint_path); return
    j = UsdPhysics.RevoluteJoint(prim)
    lo_deg = math.degrees(lower_rad)
    hi_deg = math.degrees(upper_rad)
    # Create*/Get* are equivalent for authoring; Create* guarantees the attr exists.
    j.CreateLowerLimitAttr().Set(lo_deg)
    j.CreateUpperLimitAttr().Set(hi_deg)
    print(f"[OK] Set limits on {joint_path} to [{lo_deg:.3f}°, {hi_deg:.3f}°]")

# ---- Your existing mimic fixes (keep these) ----
set_single_reference("/World/ur/joints/robotiq_85_left_inner_knuckle_joint",  "/World/ur/joints/robotiq_85_left_knuckle_joint")
set_single_reference("/World/ur/joints/robotiq_85_left_finger_tip_joint",     "/World/ur/joints/robotiq_85_left_knuckle_joint")
set_single_reference("/World/ur/joints/robotiq_85_right_inner_knuckle_joint", "/World/ur/joints/robotiq_85_left_knuckle_joint")
set_single_reference("/World/ur/joints/robotiq_85_right_finger_tip_joint",    "/World/ur/joints/robotiq_85_left_knuckle_joint")

# ---- NEW: author finite limits on both inner knuckle joints ----
# left inner knuckle: +1 mapping of source [0, 0.8] rad
set_revolute_limits_rad("/World/ur/joints/robotiq_85_left_inner_knuckle_joint",  0.0,  0.8)

# right inner knuckle: -1 mapping of source -> [-0.8, 0] rad
set_revolute_limits_rad("/World/ur/joints/robotiq_85_right_inner_knuckle_joint", -0.8, 0.0)

notes.title: Teleoperation Survey
notes.content:
# Research Summary: [Tele-operation Survey]

## Objective
Learn about the various teleoperation devices used in the community

## Key Findings
- Teleoperation as a technique can be thought of a classic Master-Apprentice relationship
- The robot the apprentice learns the craft by watching the humans, the masters at work
- Paradigm shift from coding instructions to teaching by doing
- Traditional Code - Rigid, specific and totally inflexible. Works on an assembly line
- Human Demonstrations - Fluid, intuitive. It captures not just 'what' but also 'how'
- How to Demonstrate:
 - Kin-esthetic Teaching: Physically guiding the robot's arm
 - Teleoperation: Using a joystick or simple controller
 - Immersive VR: Using a VR headset to become the robot - Most intuitive
 - Operators being able to step into the robot's body is the most intuitive way for teaching robots.
 - Immersive VR techniques lets operator's movements get consumed to directly control the gripper
   - Operator hand movement mapped one to one with the gripper
   - Operator intuition gets captured more accurately. Higher quality data
 - Apprentice Mind:
  - Imitation Learning - A paradigm where an agent learns to perform a task by mimicking the behavior of an expert.
   - Behavioral Cloning - Learn to map a specific state to a specific action
                          Not just enough to mimic the past but also learn the patterns to predict and generalize.
 - Good teaching requires a closed feedback.
  - Robot needs to 'talk' back - 
   - Augmented Reality - Visualize the planned path.
   - Haptic Feedback - Vibrates to show confidence
   - Auditory Cues - Sound to indicate status or intent



 
## Implications

## Next Steps

notes.title: 2025-08-18 — Daily
notes.content:
# Top 3
- [ ] 
- [ ] 
- [ ] 

## Tasks
Chatgpt5 Analysis:
- The performance on the MMMU metric has increased by 5%.
- Features:
 - Model Selection - gpt5 main(fast) & gpt5 thinking(reasoning) - Router(trained model on prompts) decides which model to be used for specific prompts
 - Hallucination - Typically browsing tools like RAGS are used to ground the response of the LLM models to reduce hallucination
 - Sycophancy - Because of RLHF - Mitigated with the help of System Prompts - Fragile during long conversation - Handled using Post Training
  - Models were penalized when it mistook factual agreement with tone politeness
- Safe Completion - Fully Comply or Hard Refuse - Model trained to give 3 prompts - 1) Direct Answer 2) Safe Completion 3) Refuse
- Deception - Happens when the graders during post-training rewarded confident looking answer although the reasoning behind it was invalid - GPT5 trained to Fail Gracefully and also supports 
              Chain Of Thought Monitoring - Honest and valid COT are rewarded while anything else are severely penalized. 

## Journal

## Wins
